WILMER INSTITUTE
DEDICATED TODAY
Doctor To Speak At Ceremonies Of Opening
Program
ADDRESS

BY

SATTERLEE

Authorities Ophthalmology
Here For Events
The first of the inaugural exercises of the Wilmer Ophthalmological Institute will commence today at
10 a.m., when Dr. Joseph S. Ames
delivers the dedicatory address.
These ceremonies, which purport
to the occupation of permanent
headquarters of the institute mark
the successful culmination of nine
years of prodigious planning on the
part of Dr. William H. Wilmer and
associated workers.
Dr. Wilmer At Head

Dr. Wilmer, some years back,
was one of the most prominent eyephysicians of Washington, D. C.
During that period his remarkable
efficiency and dynamic personality
won him a wide circle of friends.
In nineteen-twenty, Miss Aida
D'Acosta (now Mrs. Henry Breckinridge) became acquainted with
Dr. Wilmer as a patient. She conceived the idea of centering about
the specialist, an institute complete
in every detail, with modern facilities for treating eye diseases and
ailments.
In nineteen twenty-four, she and
her associate opened negotiations
with the Johns Hopkins University
for the furtherance of their project.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 11, 1929

Vol. XXXIV, No. 5

MACHINE AGE TO BE
SUBJECT OF LECTURE
Mr. Elmer Kenyon, a national director of the Drama
League of America and President of the Pittsburgh Drama
League will lecture at 5 P. M.
this afternoon in Levering
Hall on the "Machine Age."
This lecture is under the general auspices of the Theater
Guild. There will be an opportunity for questions and
open discussion at the conclusion of Mr. Kenyon's lecture.
The public is invited to
attend.

DR. HART SPEAKS
AT ASSEMBLY

Rifle Club Is
Dr. Mitchel to Speak
Arranging Matches
At Assembly Thursday
Dr. Broadus Mitchell, Professor
of Political Economy, will be the
speaker at this Thursday's assembly,
it was announced by Hall, President
of the Student Council. This assembly, the third of the year, will be
held in the regular place in the C.
E. Building.
Dr. Mitchell, it was also stated,
will not select the topic of his speech
until several minutes before the assembly. He is professor of the
course in Political Economy. His
talks, which he delivers at an assembly each year, have always been enjoyed by his audiences. Judging
from these former speeches, a surprise is in store for those who hear
Dr. Mitchell Thursday, for he does
not talk along cut-and-dried lines,
but is original and interesting.

DEBATING COUNCIL
MEETS WEDNESDAY
The Debating Council will
hold its organization meeting
Wednesday at 12.30 o'clock in
Levering Hall. An election
of secretary must be made, inas much as Paul Cordish has
not returned to the University.
Plans will then be formulated
for inter-class debates, varsity
debates, and for the Tocqueville medal competition. Garland Hershey, who headed the
Council last year, will probably
attend the meeting as will
William McDorman.

Having begun organization
earlier in the year, the rifle club
w ill be ready to start practice in the
rear future according to Captain
Bass, the coach of the team. The
range will be ready by next week
according to tentative plans. Twenty freshmen have joined the club
and new material is urged to apply.
In fact the club would like more
members and registration is now
open. The club expects to be thoroughly organized by next Monday.

Pennsylvania Chaplain Praises
New Levering Hall
Progress and faith formed the
text of Dr. Jack Hart's lecture at
the Levering Hall Assembly last
Thursday.
Dr. Hart, chaplain and executive
secretary of the University of
Pennsylvania, has interested himself to a great extent in students
and student activities. He obtained
his degree in psychology at that university.
Before delving into the theme of
of his lecture the Doctor complimented the Y. M. C. A. on the success of the new student activity
building. He declared its superiority
to a similar building at Penn, claiming it as the only college building
combining social service, student
workers and clubs under one roof.

JAYS LOSE
TO RICHMOND
Turnbull's Loss To Jays Felt
In Game With Spiders
GUNTER

STARS

Spiders Overcome Jays Lead
In Last Half
Uncorking a dazzling running
attack in the third and fourth quarter, the University of Richmond
defeated the Blue Jays last Saturday by the score of 21 to 7.
Outplayed in the second quarter
after they had swept the visitors
off their feet in the opening session,
the Spiders regained their stride in
the second half to shove over three
touchdowns while their opponents
registered only once.
Gunter Thrills Crowd

It was a stirring game, featured
by a sensational run by Doug Gunter, Richmond captain. He raced
75 yards behind perfect interference in the last two minutes of play
to electrify a crowd of 1,500 spectators. Gunter, reversing his field,
ran dodging, sidestepping and finally
wading the Hopkins safety man to
give the home forces their third
touchdown.
Johns Hopkins' touchdown came
in the third quarter, shortly after
Richmond had chalked up its first
counter. The Blue Jays, Mixingpasses with line plays, marched 55
yards over the Spiders' goal line.
Hudert and Merriken, in two air
thrusts, rang up a first down, with
the southpaw Guild followed with
a series of uncanny, novel passes.
Twice the Hopkins quarterback
shot the ball to Rosenberg for appreciable gains. With the ball in the
Spiders' 16-yard line, Merriken and
Hudert alternated in bucking the
line until Merriken hit the line for
two yards and a touchdown. Hudert place-kicked the extra point,
putting the Jays on equal terms
with the Richmond eleven.

October 1, 1929.
Dear Sir:

EDITORIALS
THE UNIVERSITY CELEBRATES
AST Friday, ceremonies took place which formally dedicated the

Education and marked the
L Francis P. Garvin Chair of Chemical
the selection and education of chemi-

inauguration of the new plan for
cal students. In continuance of its past record of high achievement,
the Chemistry Department takes another step forward. Congratulations
are in order.
In this present age of high pressure methods the field of science
requires men whose training is more than superficial. The new scheme
planned by Dr. Neil E. Gordon and made possible by the generosity
of Francis P. Garvin, the most prominent lay chemist of today, will go
far toward turning out men qualified to meet the increasingly complex
problems confronting chemistry. The men selected to pursue their
training here at Hopkins are supposedly of unusual ability and are to
be trained to take places in educating the chemists of tomorrow.
Though we shall probably not find any genius such as pseudo-scientist
Edison recently attempted to discover, it is, nevertheless, within the
means of this plan to select men of unusual ability and give them
every possible aid in becoming leaders in their profession. Today,
thoughtful people of financial means realize that it is wise to aid
exceptional students to pursue their training without carrying an added
burden of financial worry. Under the influence of able teachers these
students are gathered here to be trained along special lines. The Uniersity is again pioneering. Under Dr. Neil E. Gordon, holders of
fellowships from all over the United States will be trained to take
places among leaders in chemical education. To his many other contributions to chemical education, Mr. Garvin, has added this one.
Chemistry in general and the Johns Hopkins University in particular,
owe him a debt of gratitude.
* * * *
The Medical School is also celebrating the completion of two major
projects. The formal opening of the Wilmer Opthalmological Institute
is an outstanding contribution to the Medical School, Hospital and
American medicine in general. Here diseases of the eye are being
studied and numbers of sufferers are daily aided in the dispensary.
A monument to the executive ability of Dr. William H. Welch, the
Welch Medical Library stands completed.
There is perhaps no more beloved figure in American medicine than
Dr. Welch. Over seventy, he remains keen and active and it is through
his efforts that the Library has been built. For over a year Dr. Welch
wandered, literally wandered, about Europe buying books everywhere
to put on the shelves of the new building. From everywhere volumes
came back to Baltimore testifying to the enthusiastic interest with
• which Dr. Welch was plunging into this new project. Backed with
this youthful enthusiasm, the Library has been completed. Here students
will find that physical comfort so conducive to mental concentration.
Undergraduates though not actually concerned with these steps of
progress should not remain oblivious of their completion.
These events are much in the nature of a very special birthday
celebration and no loyal son of the University should neglect the event.

POLITICS
elections has always brought ward politics and

HE season of class
Thigh
pressure salesmanship prominently into the foreground of
oppor-

campus activities. No other activity of the year brings so much
tunity for shady deals and selfish alliances. It is to the lasting discredit
of any organization which lets itself be made a party to elections of
purely political nature; that is, elections in which the evidently superior
candidate is defeated by so-called combines of rival factions.
In many cases, in fact, most instances, candidates are evenly matched.
At such times there can be no harm in "playing politics" to put across
your man. The evils of the presentstate of affairs result in dissatisfaction with the whole system when such evils are allowed to exceed reasonable limits. No honor accrues to any group which elects an inferior
candidate over a superior one backed by a rival organization of less
power.
To play politics is not objectionable when the spirit of fair play is
not violated.
P. W. S.

"The new student, and intercollegiate magazine that circulates in
every college in the country, has discontinued publication because of
lack of financial support.
"The passing of the New Student marks the last of a unique venture in the publication field. For
seven years, the magazine, edited
by college students and recent graduates, has held a mirror to college
life; the files for those years are a
complete history of higher education in a changing post-war era. In
addition to news, the magazine attempted to shape educational policy
in the direction of more student
freedom and initiative against the
goose step methods. It succeeded in
making ardent friends and bitter
enemies among professors, administrators, and alumni by its forthright championing of progressive educational methods in every
occasion."
Sincerely yours,
"The New Student."

WILMER INSTITUTE
DEDICATED TODAY
Doctor To Speak At Ceremonies Of Opening
Program
ADDRESS

BY

SATTERLEE

Authorities Ophthalmology
Here For Events
The first of the inaugural exercises of the Wilmer Ophthalmological Institute will commence today at
10 a.m., when Dr. Joseph S. Ames
delivers the dedicatory address.
These ceremonies, which purport
to the occupation of permanent
headquarters of the institute mark
the successful culmination of nine
years of prodigious planning on the
part of Dr. William H. Wilmer and
associated workers.
Dr. Wilmer At Head

Dr. Wilmer, some years back,
was one of the most prominent eyephysicians of Washington, D. C.
During that period his remarkable
efficiency and dynamic personality
won him a wide circle of friends.
In nineteen-twenty, Miss Aida
D'Acosta (now Mrs. Henry Breckinridge) became acquainted with
Dr. Wilmer as a patient. She conceived the idea of centering about
the specialist, an institute complete
in every detail, with modern facilities for treating eye diseases and
ailments.
In nineteen twenty-four, she and
her associate opened negotiations
with the Johns Hopkins University
for the furtherance of their project.

Vol. XXXIV, No. 5

MACHINE AGE TO BE
SUBJECT OF LECTURE
Mr. Elmer Kenyon, a national director of the Drama
League of America and President of the Pittsburgh Drama
League will lecture at 5 P. M.
this afternoon in Levering
Hall on the "Machine Age."
This lecture is under the general auspices of the Theater
Guild. There will be an opportunity for questions and
open discussion at the conclusion of Mr. Kenyon's lecture.
The public is invited to
attend.

DR. HART SPEAKS
AT ASSEMBLY

Rifle Club Is
Dr. Mitchel to Speak
Arranging Matches
At Assembly Thursday
Dr. Broadus Mitchell, Professor
of Political Economy, will be the
speaker at this Thursday's assembly,
it was announced by Hall, President
of the Student Council. This assembly, the third of the year, will be
held in the regular place in the C.
E. Building.
Dr. Mitchell, it was also stated,
will not select the topic of his speech
until several minutes before the assembly. He is professor of the
course in Political Economy. His
talks, which he delivers at an assembly each year, have always been enjoyed by his audiences. Judging
from these former speeches, a surprise is in store for those who hear
Dr. Mitchell Thursday, for he does
not talk along cut-and-dried lines,
but is original and interesting.

DEBATING COUNCIL
MEETS WEDNESDAY
The Debating Council will
hold its organization meeting
Wednesday at 12.30 o'clock in
Levering Hall. An election
of secretary must be made, inas much as Paul Cordish has
not returned to the University.
Plans will then be formulated
for inter-class debates, varsity
debates, and for the Tocqueville medal competition. Garland Hershey, who headed the
Council last year, will probably
attend the meeting as will
William McDorman.

Having begun organization
earlier in the year, the rifle club
w ill be ready to start practice in the
rear future according to Captain
Bass, the coach of the team. The
range will be ready by next week
according to tentative plans. Twenty freshmen have joined the club
and new material is urged to apply.
In fact the club would like more
members and registration is now
open. The club expects to be thoroughly organized by next Monday.

Pennsylvania Chaplain Praises
New Levering Hall
Progress and faith formed the
text of Dr. Jack Hart's lecture at
the Levering Hall Assembly last
Thursday.
Dr. Hart, chaplain and executive
secretary of the University of
Pennsylvania, has interested himself to a great extent in students
and student activities. He obtained
his degree in psychology at that university.
Before delving into the theme of
of his lecture the Doctor complimented the Y. M. C. A. on the success of the new student activity
building. He declared its superiority
to a similar building at Penn, claiming it as the only college building
combining social service, student
workers and clubs under one roof.

JAYS LOSE
TO RICHMOND
Turnbull's Loss To Jays Felt
In Game With Spiders
GUNTER

STARS

Spiders Overcome Jays Lead
In Last Half
Uncorking a dazzling running
attack in the third and fourth quarter, the University of Richmond
defeated the Blue Jays last Saturday by the score of 21 to 7.
Outplayed in the second quarter
after they had swept the visitors
off their feet in the opening session,
the Spiders regained their stride in
the second half to shove over three
touchdowns while their opponents
registered only once.
Gunter Thrills Crowd

It was a stirring game, featured
by a sensational run by Doug Gunter, Richmond captain. He raced
75 yards behind perfect interference in the last two minutes of play
to electrify a crowd of 1,500 spectators. Gunter, reversing his field,
ran dodging, sidestepping and finally
wading the Hopkins safety man to
give the home forces their third
touchdown.
Johns Hopkins' touchdown came
in the third quarter, shortly after
Richmond had chalked up its first
counter. The Blue Jays, Mixingpasses with line plays, marched 55
yards over the Spiders' goal line.
Hudert and Merriken, in two air
thrusts, rang up a first down, with
the southpaw Guild followed with
a series of uncanny, novel passes.
Twice the Hopkins quarterback
shot the ball to Rosenberg for appreciable gains. With the ball in the
Spiders' 16-yard line, Merriken and
Hudert alternated in bucking the
line until Merriken hit the line for
two yards and a touchdown. Hudert place-kicked the extra point,
putting the Jays on equal terms
with the Richmond eleven.

October 1, 1929.
Dear Sir:

EDITORIALS
THE UNIVERSITY CELEBRATES
AST Friday, ceremonies took place which formally dedicated the

Education and marked the
L Francis P. Garvin Chair of Chemical
the selection and education of chemi-

inauguration of the new plan for
cal students. In continuance of its past record of high achievement,
the Chemistry Department takes another step forward. Congratulations
are in order.
In this present age of high pressure methods the field of science
requires men whose training is more than superficial. The new scheme
planned by Dr. Neil E. Gordon and made possible by the generosity
of Francis P. Garvin, the most prominent lay chemist of today, will go
far toward turning out men qualified to meet the increasingly complex
problems confronting chemistry. The men selected to pursue their
training here at Hopkins are supposedly of unusual ability and are to
be trained to take places in educating the chemists of tomorrow.
Though we shall probably not find any genius such as pseudo-scientist
Edison recently attempted to discover, it is, nevertheless, within the
means of this plan to select men of unusual ability and give them
every possible aid in becoming leaders in their profession. Today,
thoughtful people of financial means realize that it is wise to aid
exceptional students to pursue their training without carrying an added
burden of financial worry. Under the influence of able teachers these
students are gathered here to be trained along special lines. The Uniersity is again pioneering. Under Dr. Neil E. Gordon, holders of
fellowships from all over the United States will be trained to take
places among leaders in chemical education. To his many other contributions to chemical education, Mr. Garvin, has added this one.
Chemistry in general and the Johns Hopkins University in particular,
owe him a debt of gratitude.
* * * *
The Medical School is also celebrating the completion of two major
projects. The formal opening of the Wilmer Opthalmological Institute
is an outstanding contribution to the Medical School, Hospital and
American medicine in general. Here diseases of the eye are being
studied and numbers of sufferers are daily aided in the dispensary.
A monument to the executive ability of Dr. William H. Welch, the
Welch Medical Library stands completed.
There is perhaps no more beloved figure in American medicine than
Dr. Welch. Over seventy, he remains keen and active and it is through
his efforts that the Library has been built. For over a year Dr. Welch
wandered, literally wandered, about Europe buying books everywhere
to put on the shelves of the new building. From everywhere volumes
came back to Baltimore testifying to the enthusiastic interest with
• which Dr. Welch was plunging into this new project. Backed with
this youthful enthusiasm, the Library has been completed. Here students
will find that physical comfort so conducive to mental concentration.
Undergraduates though not actually concerned with these steps of
progress should not remain oblivious of their completion.
These events are much in the nature of a very special birthday
celebration and no loyal son of the University should neglect the event.

POLITICS
elections has always brought ward politics and

HE season of class
Thigh
pressure salesmanship prominently into the foreground of
oppor-

campus activities. No other activity of the year brings so much
tunity for shady deals and selfish alliances. It is to the lasting discredit
of any organization which lets itself be made a party to elections of
purely political nature; that is, elections in which the evidently superior
candidate is defeated by so-called combines of rival factions.
In many cases, in fact, most instances, candidates are evenly matched.
At such times there can be no harm in "playing politics" to put across
your man. The evils of the presentstate of affairs result in dissatisfaction with the whole system when such evils are allowed to exceed reasonable limits. No honor accrues to any group which elects an inferior
candidate over a superior one backed by a rival organization of less
power.
To play politics is not objectionable when the spirit of fair play is
not violated.
P. W. S.

"The new student, and intercollegiate magazine that circulates in
every college in the country, has discontinued publication because of
lack of financial support.
"The passing of the New Student marks the last of a unique venture in the publication field. For
seven years, the magazine, edited
by college students and recent graduates, has held a mirror to college
life; the files for those years are a
complete history of higher education in a changing post-war era. In
addition to news, the magazine attempted to shape educational policy
in the direction of more student
freedom and initiative against the
goose step methods. It succeeded in
making ardent friends and bitter
enemies among professors, administrators, and alumni by its forthright championing of progressive educational methods in every
occasion."
Sincerely yours,
"The New Student."

the students. He spoke of the City
of Baltimore and the advantages it
offered to students. Dr. French
said, "to use the City of Baltimore
as the laboratory of Human Interests and Human Emotions." The
climate of Baltimore was acclaimed
to be the best in the East with our
short winter, beautiful autumn, and
unsurpassable spring. He mentioned
the beauties of the countryside,
urging the students to make use of
their automobiles, if they "had
brought one along as an aid to their
education," or to take walks if not
so fortunate as to possess one of
Henry Ford's marvelous contraptions.

Dr. Prettyman confessed that
there was an alterior motive in inviting the students to the dinner.
This motive was to invite them to
come to church. He then gave reasons why the men should attend
church; first saying that it would
do them no harm. His second reason was that it would cost nothing;
for if alone the collection plate need
not be noticed, while if accompanied
by a young, fair friend a nickel
hidden under the thumb might pass
for someone elses dollar. Thirdly,
it would not disturb the thinking
of the students.
